concept.title: The outputclass attribute
concept.shortdesc: When you need an element to appear differently in the output from other elements with the same semantics, you can provide a value in the element's outputclass attribute.

conbody.p: Most block and phrase elements in DITA have an outputclass attribute. This attribute is used to provide output styling information, when necessary.
When published to an HTML-based output format, the value in the outputclass attribute of an element will be passed through to the CSS class attribute in the HTML code.

You should avoid using the outputclass attribute, as it is not a semantic marker. The presentation of the output should be determined by the publishing tool automatically converting semantic mark-up to formatting rules.

section.title: Supplementary Information
section.p: When generating HTML output from DITA source through the Open Toolkit, you can't have one topic attached to one CSS and another to another. However, you can use the outputclass element attribute to nominate a non-standard CSS class for a particular heading or paragraph, and then define that different class in the CSS file. That would be the way to make one topic look different from the others.
